Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

FRIDAY, March 10, 1905.

div.head: The Battle of Mukden
div.p: The great fight that has now been raging for some days around Mukden will, to all appearances, be hereafter considered one of the decisive battles of the world's history; and the great military catastrophe in Manchuria may well be decisive not merely of the war but of the future of Russian autocracy. While the Government is paralysed by the Terror at home the news from General Kuropatkin's army is ominous. There is no longer doubt that Oyama's true strategical objective has at last been attained, and that the Japanese are in the rear of Kuropatkin and have out to the north the railway on which the existence of the Russian armies depend. Now, unless the Japanese are driven off, which is a most unlikely contingency, Russia will be brought face to face with a tragedy, beside which all that Russia has as yet suffered of disaster and humiliation would be as nothing.

It is worth while pausing to consider what the consequence must necessarily be. it must be admitted that in the present case it will be staggering. Not only will the present regime be thrown overboard, and, possibly, even a wholly different form of government imposed. It is not only that the traditional policy of Russia for many generations will, as a matter of necessity, be abandoned, and a wholly different set of activities and developments pursued in its place. Were these all, there might be found more than one parallel for the situation, something to suggest the future of this enormous people. But the real change lies deeper that (TOP the evolution of 9 new dynasty, or

form of government, or national object is nothing less than the decontiuenl of an entire people. The face of Russ the past been set wholly towards the There was some justification for these vast majority of her people were neither anxious for European methods of gave they were content to accept the patriarchal tyranny of the auto divinely ordained necessity in a inanely different from that in which those of Afghanistan acquiesce in the ai of their Amir. We do not propose into the question whether a citing nature would or would not prove date advantage or secure any suits libration of the lot of the commotion of Russia. Only we invite those this unexpectedly sudden evolution tonal independence is a real and only a curious interest to realise t truth which it contains. Pushed to i conclusion, this present rising may the addition of Russia not nowise but actually, to the number of the nations of the old world..

That this—at any rate what 'this is by no means the .wish of the existing meat of Russia, will not, we iinagtui puled, but we are inclined to think should come at all, it will come in the have suggested, and that by the barrier which the Grand Dukes raL afternoon between the people and there has come first paralysis in the of the present war, and only alter tin remedy a reformation of every patron of the existing regime.

div.head:
KUROPATKIN's danger.
RAILWAY LINE CUT.
JAPS ADVANCING ON HUN-HO

div.p: The Japanese have cut the railway north of Mukden. (Reuter. /

The consummate strategy of the Japanese, . .\k;uplified in the operations round Mukden, is universally acknowledged. 'It is believed •Li* tin* Japanese, profiting by the mistake -i.idea'i hia«' yang, ' Irnvp concentrated abundant forces along the line «-f retreat, in order to bring about an overwhelming defeat.
Experts draw attention to the fact that the whereat units of Kawawiira's army, consisting of sixdivisions, is absolutely unknown. (It.)
The Japanese have cut the railway to the north of Mukden. (Havas.)
The telegrams from Oyaiua and Kuropatkin indicate that fierce fighting is proceeding T -rth-Wost of Mukden. (Reuter.)

'Several Russian counter attacks at Yenshihand Likuatipu, west of Mukden, have been repuled with heavy loss, The Japanese have occupied Siaochitun, five miles north-west, and Santaitsu, five miles north, of Mukden. (R.)
Reuter's Agency learns from Mukden on the sih inst. that on the southern front the Japanese are fast advancing on the Hun-Ho, where the Russians expect to make a stand,
the issue depends on the operations northward along the railway. (Reuter.)
Strong forces have been sent to deal with the peasant risings in the provinces of Orel and Tchernigoff, where bauds of men, thousands strong, are looting and burning the estates.
(Reuter.)

div.head: Cairo of To day. —
div.p: Messrs. A. .and C. Black have just issued the fourth edition ol ibis very bandy little guide to Cairo and the Nile. The book, while not of course enabling the tourist to dispense with his Baedeker or Murray, forms au excellent substitute for the more bulky guides while on tour, being so woll-arranged that reference is easy in every way. We notice, however, that the author, Mr. Keyuolds-Ball, B.A., has failed to mention, in bis chapter on the regeneration of Egypt, the very important matter of the Anglo French Agreement recently concluded. In oilier respects the book appears to be well up to date, and it is published at tho moderate price of half-a-crown.

div.head:
Russians in the Red Sea
"Massilia" Meets Torpedo- Boats.
div.p: Suez, Thursday.

The Anchor liner "Massilia," which arrived at Suez this forenoon, reports that at 2 o'clock this morning she passed seven torpedo-boats cruising about near Ras Garib. One of them came alongside tho steamer, and then followed at a distance for some time. Owing to the darkness the "Masailia" conic! not distinguish the nationality of the warships, which are no doubt Russian.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR GARRISON.
div.p: Port Said, Thursday.

The Nfirth German Lloyd 8.S. "Zieten," which arrived at Port Said early this morning from Yokohama, brought 119 Russian soldiers and 66 Government officials and clerks from Port Arthur. They leave to-day for Odessa by the Russian steamer.

div.head: THE STRANDING OF THE "CAIRO."
div.p: The commission of enquiry at midday to day proceeded to the spot where the S.S. "Cairo" lies stranded, and was conducting investigations as we went to press.
The crow of the vessel left yesterday for Italy by the Flurio-Kubattiuo S.S. "Singapore" en route for Genoa. Only six remained here, including Captain de Marchi, in connection with the inquiry.

Signor Novelli and his company have changed their methods of legal attack, and intend suing the captain of the "Cairo" personally, the Fiorio-Kubattino Steam Navigation Company, and the Administration of the Port ot Alexandria. The case will be heard on Monday next at the Mixed Courts before the tribunal des liters." Maitre Guidotti will represent the plaiutiils, who demand the nomination of our or of three experts to determine who is responsible for the accident, and to ascertain especially whether the alleged carelessness to the Ports and Lighthouses Administration contributed materially to the damage done to the vessel.
Many otters have been made to the company to refloat the steamer, but nothing has, of yet, been decided.
'1 tic steamer is not insured.
As to the cargo, most the greater part was insured, it has been taken in charge by the companies affected, who will deal with the question of salvage.

div.head: THE ROYAL BETROTHAL.
div.p: The betrothal of Princess Margaret of Connaught to Prince Gustavus Adolphus has a special interest for historical genealogists. At the present moment the only European throne except the not very glorious or -enviable one of Scrvia and that of Turkey, not occupied by a direct descendant of our own king James 1., is the throne of the Beruadottes. The natural consequence, if all goes well, of the marriage of Princess Margaret to the eldest son of the Crown Prince of Norway and Sweden will be that that throne, too, will m course of time be occupied by a descendant of James I.

div.head: SHEPHEARD'S VENETIAN FETE.
div.p: At 10 o'clock last night, the beautiful garden behind Shcpheard's Hotel was filled with a large and animated crowd who had been attracted thither by the promise of fireworks and of illuminations on a large scale. The whole of the garden had been hung with multicoloured Chinese lauterus in tasteful design, and there being no moon, the effect produced was extremely picturesque. Electric lights had also been fixed in many of the trees, and the rose-coloured lamps ou the tops of the highest palms completed a very pretty sight.

The fireworks were greatly appreciated and confetti were thrown with such vigour, and in such quantity, that the paths were in places almost ankle-deep. In spite of its being rather a cold night, the gardens were thronged till a ate hour, while dancing went on in the Moorish central hall till long after midnight A large number of well-known Cairo residents, including many of the officers of the British and Egyptian forces, took part in the festivities, and with them were a great number of tourists, principally American, who all seemed to be enjoying themselves immensely.

Among the diners in the restaurant, we noticed 11.1.H. Prince Adalbert of Prussia, with a party of six, among whom was Dr. Rucker-Jenish, German Consol General. Mrs. Carey also entertained a party of six, and other parties were those of Mr. Rutherford, Mr. Devries, Mr. Hiller, Mr. Moroom, etc.
Others to be seen in the restaurant were the Rt. Hon. J. W. Mellor, Baron Vogel von Falkenstein, Lady Bell, Countess Holnstein, and Vicomte de Sapucahi.
The Egyptian Infantry band discoursed a programme of music in one of the comers of the garden, while the dance music was provided by the Tzigane orchestra, whoso playing was much appreciated.

There were many supper parties in the grillroom and the gathering did not disperse till nearly 2 o'clock this morning. Our thanks are due to Mr. Baehler and his able staff for a very enjoyable evening.

div.head: MARRIAGE OF LIEUT.-COL. KENNA.
div.p: The marriage of Lieutenant-Colonel P. A. Keuua, V.C., D.6.O., 21st Lancers (Empress of India's), wno is of course well-known in Egypt, with Angela Mary, youngest daughter ot tiie late Mr. Hubert Hiboert and Mrs. Hiobert, ot Beaufort-gardens, was celebrated at the Orator)', London, ou the 2ud mat. The long aisle and portico were lmed by non-com- mibsioned officers and troopers of the bridegroom s regiment. Colonel Powle supported ms brother officer as best man. The bride was accompanied by her brother, Mr. Washington Hibbert, 2nd King's Own Lancasters, and wore a gown of white satin and chiffon with Court train of satin veiled with sequined uet, and draped with Brussels lace, the gifl of her grandmother, Mrs. Hornyold, aud she held a bouquet ot white orchids. There were ten bridesmaids, two o! whom bore the bride's tram. They were in frocks ol white chiffon over glac4 silk, with pale blue sashes and blue hats tied with chiffon strings. Each wore ,a moonstone pendant with gold chain, on which were the initials of the wearer in diamonds, and carried a bouquet of daffodils tied with long pale blue nbbon. The Rev. Vincent Hornyold officiated, and the other priests were Father Sebastian Bowden, S J., the Rev. Odo Laugdale, O.8.B., oousin of the bride, the Rev. F. Knapp, and the Rev. Bernard Vaughan, S,J. Lady Lovat lent her house in Grosvenor-gardens for the reception. Princess Henry of Battenberg's gift to the bridegroom was a silver cream ewer and sugar bowl, and Princess Louise of Schleswig-Holstein sent him enamel aleeve- linkB. The colonel and officers of the 21st Lancers presented him with a silver tray.

div.head:
THE EGYPTIAN ESTATES LTD.
OPINIONS ON THE ISSUE.
div.p: A financial authority writes :—The promo tion of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, is one of the fairest that 1 know oL The only mistake in the prospectus, to my mind, is the omission to state two points, which, instead of being against; are distinctly in favor of the company. The first is that the directors have taken powers to issue £1,000.000 of debentures. Presumably they would not pay more than 4^ per cent for these and, taking for the sake of argument that they could only make 6^ per cent, on their investments in this country, this would give an extra profit of 4 per cent, on the 500,000 shares capital, quite apart from the profits derived from the investment of the £500,000. The second point that does not appear to be clearly stated in the prospectus is that the ordinary shares not only receive a preferential dividend at 5 per cent but accumulative preferential dividend. They then receive 65 per cent, or two- thirds of the balance, and the directors have full powers to create a general reserve fund before anything can be pai l to tbe deferred shareholders. It /is obvious that the people connected with the company are men of the highest integrity, and that a man, such as Mr. Greville Palmer, who has been director of the Bank of Egypt for 28 years, would not lend his name to any shady adventure.
Another correspondent writes:—

Mrs. Stanford, the wealthy American lady who used to visit Egypt annually, and was very weL known up the Njle, is reported to have beer poisoned by strychnine at Honolulu. It il stated that the poison was contained in « bottle of bicarbonate of soda, which she bought originally at Adelaide, in Australia, and got refilled at San Francisco. The deceased lady, who was eighty years of age, was extremely wealthy, and professed to be infeai of a plot against her life. She fied to Honolqlaq to secure, as she said, greater safety. Her Am* rican relatives authorised a statement, completely rejecting the poison theory, exphnning that Mrs. Stanford had been very ill physic&Uj and mentally, and was a victim to hallucina tions, the strongest being that her life was in danger. She died at her hotel, after returning from a picnic with her attendants.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: TRIBUNAE MIXTE
M. Zola contre le Grand Orient
d'Egypte

L'ingénieur Zola eat en Egypte depuis 1 année 1863. De 1874 à 1886 il a exécuté d'importants travaux publia C'est lui qui, tandis qu'il dirigeait encore l'association maçonnique en Yëçnt membre lé Général Garibaldi qui se déclara honoré de s'appeler son frère "Mi onoro di chiainnrvilratello". Entrepreneur très estimé et personne très aisée, M.'Zola fut, en 1872, pat sùîte des démissions de S. A. le Prince Halim Pacha, 61s du Grand Mohamed Aly, élu par l'Assemblée Générale, Grand Maître du Grand Orient d'Egypte et il prit possession definitive de sa charge le 21 mars 1873.

Ace moment l'Ordre se prouvait* dans un état de désorganisation complète, il y avait tout à refaire et mèin& à créer • locaux, ameublements, impression des statuts, rituels, diplômes, patentes, bibliothèques, bureaux, etc. Il fallait aussi faire face aux frais considérables de location, illuminations, employés, etc. tandis que la caisse était parfaitement vide.

La commission financière qui fut nominee quelques temps après, en mai 1873, et Composée du marquis do Baurogard, du chev. P. L. Dilberoglu et du professeur F. F. Oddi, trouva que les frais de l'ordre s'étaieut élovéa dans ce court espace de temps à 146.206 francs, tandis que les encaissements avaient été de 1889 francà seulement pour la même période. C'était donc un déficit de 144,317 francs.

Or cette somme de 144.317 lrancsavait été avancée par M. Zola dont l'ordre restait par conséquent le débiteur. En déduisaut do cette somme une partie dont il fit abandon à l'ordre, il restait créancier pour la somme de 118.543 francs.

L'assemblée extraordinaire à laquelle le rapport financier de la Commission fut soumis manifesta toute sa gratitude pour la donation de son président. Des adresses aflluèreut rédigées dans les termes les plus flatteurs. C'était de l'admiration, de l'enthousiasme.

Il s'agissait de payer le solde de la créance. Le Grand Orient qui n'avait encaissé en 4 ans que la somme de 1,889 francs 50 centimes se tronvait dans l'iinpoa^ibilité dele faire. Dans 1 intérêt de M* Zola et pour l'honneur de l'ordre, la Commission Financière proposa.de faire un prêt pour la somme de 130,000 francs an moyen d'une émission d'une quantité d'obligations, amortissables en 14 ans, avec intérêt de 12 % l'an (intérêt légal à cette époque). Cette proposition lut adoptée par l'A«semblée Générale. Ces obligations au nombre do 1,450 émises le 5 mai 1878 furent consignées à M. Zola et devaient être payées à l'expiration des 14 ans, intérêt et capital.

Mais qu'arrive-t-il ? En 1879 la Grande Loge, qui compose l'Assemblée Générale du Grand Orient, se sépare du Grand Orient et se constitue en corps indépendant sous la dénomination "Grande Loge Nationale d'Egypte". En se séparant elle prend à sa charge uue partie dq la dette,soit 905 obligations. Mais le 23 avril 1891, M. Zola se voit acculé à une transaction avec la Grande Loge et obligé d'accepter en échange de ces 905 obligations, qui représentaient à cette époque, en capital et intérêts, la somme de 242,540 francs, uue bagatelle de 31,096 fronts, moyennant laquelle il devait renoncer à toute réclamation ultérieure.

Restait h encaisser les autres 640 obligations. En 1901 M. Zola se résout h en réclamer le paétfnent du Suprême Conseil qui s'était engagé à les lui payer. Le tribunal auquel il dut en référer, rejeta sa demande et la Cpur confirma ee premier jugement par son arrêt du 1er avril 1902.

Aujourd'hui M. Zola fait de nouveau appel et réclame pour ses 640 obligations 74,413 francs de capital, et 135,040 fraucs d'intérêts. 11 prouve 1'exiBteuce d'un seul Grand Orient au moment où la dette fut contractée et dit que l'existence simultanée de deux Grand Orient en Egypte n'a été imagiuée par l'adversaire que pour arriver à établir qu'il avait été intégralement payé de sa créance. C'est à tort a/oate-t-il, qu'on voudrait aujourd'hui lui opposer la chose jugée eu ce qui concerne le Suprême Couseil des 33 rite écossais, ancien et acoepté, qui, selon l'arrêt, serait d'origine espagnole et qui n'a eu naissance qu'eu 1876 seulement, à savoir postérieurement à la nais- sanoe de sa créance. Il avait cru ce Suprême Couseil valablement engagé par le fait de son président Me Figari. C'est donc à tort que les premiers juges ont déclaré que si le Grand Orient aujourd'hui assigué pouvait être confondu avec la Grande Loge Natiouale d'Egypte, il pourrait opposer au concluant la transaction intervenue le 17 mai 1891. Eu effet, les dépens portés en l'Etat déposé sub N 1 avaient été faits par le concluant dans l'intérêt du.Grand Orient d'Egypte dès 1873 jusqu'à fin 1875, et il est établi au procès que la Grande Loge du dit Grand Orient ne s'est séparée de celui-ci que bien plus tard, à savoir en 1879,en prenant le nom de Grande Loge Nationale d'Egypte.
(Extrait des conclusions Zola)

div.head: TRIBUNAL CONSULAIRE DE FRANCE
div.p: Le faux Sorcier i>b Tunis
Une curieuse affaire vient d'avoir son épi loguc devant le Tribunal Consulaire de Franco à Alexandrie.

Au mois de Novembre dernier, plainte fut portée par un courtier à la bourse de notre ville, contre un Tunisien, sujet local, Hadji el Arbi ben Aly el Gharbi pour une escroquerie qui aurait été commise dans des conditions impliquant une grande naïveté de la part de la victime.

D'après le récit du plaignant, des amis l'avaient engagé à consulter au sujet d'une maladie dont souffrait depuis longtemps sa * fillette, sans que les médecins parvinssent à la souUQtfj le (rtêveno, arrivé récemment de Tüùie âVeo une grande réputation de sorcier et magicien.
Hadji el Arbi beu Aly-el-Gharbi se montra digne de sa haute réputation.
11 remit au coùïtièr Une petite boîte contenant une poudre magique et prononça quelques paroles mystérieuses. La fillette ayant pris la poudre guérit aussitôt sans avoir même vu son guérisseur.
Cette cure miraculeuse inspira au père une grande confiance dans le pouvoir occuhe du sorcier tunisien, de sorte qu'il le consulta but le moyen de faire rapidement fortune.
Le sorcier ne lui donna pas de tuyau sor la National Bank ou la Darru San it h tuais il l'engagea à 1m apporter une somme en livres d'or, aussi to rtc que possible.
Dans sa candeur, le courtier aurait remis 102 livres au magicien qui les palpa, les mit en rouleaux et les plaça dans un coffret, tout en proférant des incantations.

Puis il invita le courtier à fermer le coffret à clef, et à l'emporter chez lui et à ne l'ouvrir qu'aprèâ un délai de onze jours, nécessaire jpour que les formules magiques pussent produire tout leur effet Alors sa fortune serait faite.
Pour sa rémunération, le sorcier se fit signer par le courtier un billet à ordre du montant de 70 francs.
Dans son impatience, le courrier ne put pas attendre l'espaco fatidique de onze jours prescrits.

Vingt quatre heures après l'audience que lui avait accordée le magicien, il ouvrit le ooffret pour voir si l'effet des incantations ne commençait pas à se produire. Il trouva que l'effet était eutièremeut réalisé puisque les livres en or avaieut disparu et étaient remplacées par dos piles de vulgaires piastres courantes.
Dans sou juste ressentiment, le courtier s'adressa aux autorités consulaires françaises qui envoyèrent Hadji el Arbi beu Aly el Gharbi en prison. .
Cette affaire de sorcellerie est venue la semaine dernière devant le Tribunal Consulaire de France qui lui a consacré deux longues audieuces. 4

Le prévenu, un bel homme, à la figure sympathique et de superbe prestance s'est défendu avec éaergie de l'accusation)^ portée contre lui. Sans aucuue difficulté, il a reconnu s'occuper de médeciue et de cabale pour son agrémeut personnel, tnais a déclaré n'avoir jamais fait le métier de diseur de bonue aventure.
Par une habile contre attaque il a représenté le plaignant comme un vulgaire filou qui u'avait jamais possédé 102livres, ui même moins, et qui cherchait à s enrichir aux dépens du prévenu.

Après avoir euteudu 25 témoins tant à charge qu'à décharge et uue brillante plaidoirie de Me Achille de la Pommeraye eu faveur de l'accusé, le Tribunal a acquitté Hadji el Arbi ben Aly el Gharbi, estimaut que la préveution u'était pas établie.
Avec uue-graude courtoisie ot beaucoup de dignité, le faux-sorcier de Tunis a remercié le Tribunal et son avocat, eu proclamant de nouveau son innocence.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Wakfs privés de S.A. le'Khédive met eu adjudication les deux entreprises des travaux nécessaires aux façades Est et Ouest de la mosquée d'El-Rtfaï.
La présentation des offres aura lieu jusqu'au lundi 20 mars 1905 à 10 heures du matin.

Tous ceux qui désireront concourir à cette adjudication pourront prendre connaissanoe des plans, dessins et cahiers des chargea à l'administration des Wakfs au Palais d'Abdine ou au bureau situé à la maison No. 35, rue El- Maghrabi vis-à-vis de la bourse, tous les jours de 3 b. à 5 b. de l'après-midi excepté les vendredis et les jours de fête.
Les offres, qui devront être faites pour char que façade séparémeut, seront adressées sous pli cacheté au Directeur des Wakis Khédiviaux privés et porteront le uom de l'entrepreneur.
Les coucurreuts devront se présenter à l'administration à la date fixée munis des garanties nécessaires.

Les offres faites après le délai sus-mentionné ou qui ne seront pas accompagnées desgaranties ne seront pas admises. 11 en est de même des offres présentées sous un nom collectif ou celui d'une société.
L'administration se réserve le droit d'accepter ou de refuser toute offre sans en donner les motifs.
Les garanties pour les travaux sus-mentionnés sont les suivantes : 280 LE. pour démolition, reconstruction et travaux d'em- bellÎBsement de la façade Est.
350 LE. pour démolition et escalier eu marbre de ia façade Ouest. 25565-3 1

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: The trade in Egyptian yarns continues very unsatisfactor, and there being no indeucemtn for spinners to buy more cotton than for their immediate requirements, prices are irregular at unchanged rates.
Futures have been fairly active this week, and the following represent the latest values.
March 6.44 May 6.31 July 6.25
April 6.37 June 6.29 Aug 6.24 Nov. 6.13

American Futures. The market this week has been less active, but there have been frequent fluctuations. To-day's closing values are 7 @ 6 points lower than those of last Thursday, the distant positions have declined the most. There is no new feature, there is an absensce of speculative interest, and the Market is almost entirely in the hands of professional traders. Better weather in the Cotton area has casued sligjtly increased crop movements, but so far planters do not show signs of selling more freely and the preparations for planing the next crop are very backward. The condition and tone of the market reflect the general absence of any decidied opinion, no one seems to know whether to buy or to sell is better, and so most people decide for the moment, at any rate, to look on.

div.head: EGYPT AND SUDAN MINING.
div.p: A DIVIDEND OF 100 PER CENT. - INCREASE OF CAPITAL

last, annual meeting, held in February', Uni t, they were atill engaged in development uurk upon tile dudau Concession, which they had been exploring lorwometwo or three years. That development work was then confined to the Oui Nuoauli mine, where they had succeeded in discovering reefs ul very great promise, and they mentioned that the operations were passing beyond the prospecting stage, a\id that the time was arriving when the necessary capital ahould be provided fur equipping the mine, and lor its mure extended exploration, both laterally and in depth. Their scheme having becu mu* lured they, parly in June last, caused to v registered the Sudan Cold Field, Limited, with*a capital of £300,000, divided into *,000 shaics of £1 each, to acquire' all their interests, rights and benehts in tho con* cestiou* Ul the nominal capital, £125,000 was set aside as working capital, and the balance ok £175,000 formed the purchase consideration, payable as to £30,000 in cash ami £145,oOo in iuiiy-paiti shares. The com* j any received applications lor some 107,000 • li-dc», ieitving-a balance of about 43,000 .Mv>ued. A lew -mouth* later a great lin- j t Aeineul happily occurred Hi the Egy pt uml budaii Section ol the'Mining Maiket, with the result mat the uliuioui the uuissued 'shared Mete readily taken up so that the Sudan Company tuts now its whole £155,000 oi cash apital iully subscribed, of winch £125,OuO is working capital.

With regard to the concession held in Egypt, that has not been up to the present so proa mining as the cue in the Euduu. They have, however, discovered upon it several reels, some i>i which have developed lairly extensively— viz., at iiamesh and bamut. Culortuuately, howeveri at those centres, whilst the reefs have been aunlerous and sometimes of considerable promise, they have so far tailed to prove ol a pay able value. Recently they have been concentrating their attention upon Dun gash and iLriahme, where old workings are fiiso found, and at the former tirtj prospects are at present most encouraging. The deepest level now 1U3 It. from surface, and some samples recently received from their superintendent m Kjypl, Mr. Donnai, taken from this level, have ' ecu tested in London, with most favorable results, the assay values ranging from 7 dwts iip^p 3 uzs 3 dwtsol gold per ton. They are to ixmtinuu to opuu up the Dungash mine, and with that view are now sinking the No. 3 shaft [or a further level in depth. At Barrahine they have nut yet done much work, but they are very hopeful that both at Dungash and Barrahine they muy succeed in opening up profitable reefs.in their report the directors have referred it some length to the new concession in the Berber district which was granted to them some little time agu by the «Sudan Government. Over Uiia property, which comprises some 15,000 square miles, they hold directly from the budoii Government an exclusive prospecting licence for throe years Hum December 1st, l jul, Mr. Llewellyn made ii preliminary examination*of this area, with be result that it was decided to despatch an expedition to the property to investigate close- iy some ol the old woikings,which he had met xith. That expedition arrived on the property in December last, and work is now being arried on at two centres—Negem and Hasliim At Negem they have exceedingly good prospects. At Hasliim they have numerous reels, which, however, at suiface appear to be of low ijrude. The most promising of the reefs will lie tested by putting down trial pits upon them, and we hope that we may tiud them more productive as we get below the surface. The Suakin Mining Syndicate, in which this syndicate holds 5,IKK) partly-paid

diares and 1,250 fully-paid shares, has pros peeling rights over a large concession in the Suakiu district of the Sudan. The considerable interests which this syndicate holds in Egypt ind the Sudan, and tho large amount of capital it has been successful in introducing for the exploration of its properties, have caused the directors to be approached with Hers of further concessions. In connection with two of the properties recently brought to their notice, they were able to arrange for the necessary time lor their cursory examina tiou, and they at once despatched an engineer selected by the managers, Messrs,. John Taylor and Sons, to make such examination on the spot Should the engineer's report be favor able, the di ts wJJ theu endeavour to form a syudicat-» ^whose capital they would probably underwrite) to acquire an assignment of tho licensee's rights over oue of these areas, and to undertake prospecting operations, with the view to the flotation of a company in the future, in the eveut of the reefs proving of a payable character, in connection with the other area, which has to some extent already been developed, should the preliminary investi gation lead the directors to regard it as a sufficiently promising mining venture, they would within the next twelve months use their best endeavours to f rrn a company to take it over. Aiter going through theaccounts theCbaiiman concluded by sayipg : "We came to the conclu Sion tliat we could pay a dividend at the rate of 100 per cent., and that the cash received, together with the cosh already in band, after paying out what wo had to pay out in cash,

permitted us to recommend the payment of ono-quarar of tho 100 per cent in cash, and that the remaining three fourths should be satisfied by the issue of a portion of the fully- paid shares wo have received."
At a subsequent extraordinary general meeting the resolution to iucrease the capital by 27,500 shares of £1 each was carried unanimously.

div.head: Letters to the Editor
div.p: We do not hold oursleesc for the responsible opinions expressed by our correspondents but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.
RELIGION IN THE SCHOOLS
To the editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir, - Will you allow me a space in your columns to bring the notice of the authorities of our country the great inconvenience and annoyance arising from the reply of the Education department sent to the Legislative Council on the question of teaching the Islam faith and religion in public schools. THe ministry of Public Instruction says "that owing to the numerous subjects that to be taught in the Government schools, it is hardly possible to find the time of teaching same." Such being the case I consider that no such trifiling reason should be a hindrance to the carrying out of the wishes of Legislative Counscil.

Religion being, as everyone understands a defence agsinst evil passions, the path of righteousness in this world and the means of our being numbered among the pure and innocent in the social life, it is very necessary for us to highly train spirited and noble youths who will shortly remove from school and be introduced to the world. Let me say with the deepest regret that Egyptians now-a-days, especially those Muslems young school-fellows, do not carea a bit for attending prayers, even to acquire a slight knowledge of the fundamental principles of their religion, not to endeavor themsleves to hear a preacher at one of our Friday Prayers ; our social will be ruined in the cursh and vanities of the fashionable world.

In conclusion I beg to draw the critical eyes of our esteemed authorities ot the following suggestions and hope my bullet will not miss its mark. Rligion may be taught to all the scholars of the Government schools in a sample gallery of the premises, the pupils standing in an 'attention' manner, and the heads of the schools, or any of the noble and well-qualified staff, giving a lecture and reading a chapter of the Koran with a simple explaination. This service may be held daily in the morning for 30 minutes. In carrying out scuh a scheme through all schools we combine two desired objects, viz. keeping time, and seeking the welfare of schoolboys, byimparting the knowledge of God offered in the Koran. I hope this matter may be discussed by our papers.- I am. etc.,
Mohamed Shefik
Headmaster, Arab's School.

div.head: THE S.P.C.A
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir, - In common with many of my fellow-citizens, I am curious to know what is the society which is styled in the article of to-day in the "Gazette". The S.P.C.A in Egypt." Like the author of this article, "we therefore venture to appea to our vistiors to remember that there are other places in Egypt besides Ccairo, Luxor, and Assouan," and we venture, at the same time, to remind him of what he has evidently alloewd to escape hisobservation of his memory, viz. : that there is not only a sea-coast village called Alexandria, but that there is another S. P. C. A., in that locality, of elecen years standing, with an equal, if not superior, claim to the proud title assumed in the article; and that, like the S.P.C.A., 'having done great things in a limited area and with limited resources, it needs to help to enable it to continue and to extend its work." Unfortunately, this S.P.C.A not havnig its headquarters in the Metropolis where hotels, crowded for three months in the year with wealthy tourists, afford a ready means of obtaining pecuniary assistance, is necessarily supported entirely by contributions from the local residents.
S. P. C. A. of A.

div.head: EASTERN SUDAN.
THE NEW MISSION OF C.M.S.
div.p: The C. M. Intelligencer says ; — "Lord Cromer, and the Sirdar at Khartoum ( Sir Reginald Wingate), while they have felt compelled to restrict the society's plans for communicating the Gospel message to the Mohamedans, have always expressed their desire to see missions established among the Pagan tribes of the Upper Nile about which there need be no scruple. They have approved of tho American Presbyterians going up to the Sobat River, whore an excellent Industrial mission has been started ; and of the Austrian Roman Catholics going south-west to the territory of the Bahr-el-Ghazal. And more than two years Ago Lord Cromer expressed the satisfaction it would Afford him if a British misrion also coiild occupy some part of those immense territories. Lord Cromer has renewed his request, and the society is entering with great hopefulness on this new field of operation." "This," says the C. M. Intelligencer, 'Ha no doubt the most important opening for the society's effort since Mr. Stanley's effort for Uganda in 1875,"

div.head: THE RAILWAY REPORT.
div.p: The following is the text of the Railway commision's note on the engineering department: -

The organisation of this department is not established on a convenient or economical basis, and the proposed expenditure of large sums of money points to the necessity of putting it on a sounder footing as soon as possible. It is believed that thestaff is capable of considerable reduction, though the employment of extra assistance may be needful for a time. Such reduction cau well be effected by reducing the amount of unnecessary correspondence that now takes place, and by the employment of contractors or piece workers to a considerable extent in place of day labour. On the occasion of this in-'pec iuu some inconvenience has been caused by the absence of plans and estimates for the different projects to be considered. It is highly desirable that in every case possible, a plau and estimate should be prepared in conjunction with other departments concerned, and it is only by attention to such points that economy and efficiency can be secured.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: FOOTBALL.
SAINT ANDREW'S FOOTBALL CLUB, c. R. BERKS* SIGNALLERS.

This match was played on the ground of the former at Moharrem Bey on Saturday last under ideal weather conditions. The home team won the toss, and Gleed started the game for the visitors. Gough and Jones took possession immediately, and a combined run by the whole front liue brought the Saints iu front of Quartennan, whom Partridge beat, when tho game was only a minute old. Two minutes later the same player, agjriu aided by beautiful combination on the part of the forwards and half backs coinbiued,repeated this performance, and thus the homo team stood two goals up. The visitors now settled down, and Huut and Borner transferred play to Curtis's end, but the home custodian was all there. On several occasions Dovey and lumau looked dangerous, but their shooting was a little off. Both teams were now having a fair Bbare of the play, and both keepers were tested in turn, but up to the interval no lurther scoring took place. »

On resuming the Signallers forced matters, and Berner looked like getting through, but Hopkins, who was plaj ing a hue game, cleared in masterly fashion. Still the visitors pressed, and success at last came their way, Dovey scoring from well out. The visitors were now having most of the play, but Keill and Hop- kius were playing a safe game, and the attempts of the forwards to find the net were repeatedly foiled. The JSaints got away, on jibe right, but Austin cleared, and later Jones tested Quartennan with a. smart shot. Partridge had a nice opening but Keen anticipated. Time arrived with Saint Andrew's pressing. Full time score: Saint Andrew's 2, Signalleis 1.
The following were the teams :—
Signallers : — Quartennan, Keen* Austin, Savin, Boyles, Jarvis, Inman, Dovey, Gleed, Hunt, and Burner.
Saint Andrew's : — Curtis, Hopkins, Keill, Williams, MacLardy, Mace, Sweet, Gough, Jones, Partridge, and Tulloch.
Referee : W. J. B. Webb.
Auother match has been arranged between the Saint Audrew's Club and the Royal Berks' Drummers, for to-morrow, on Mohurrem Bey Common. Kick off at 3.30.

Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

row.cell:
VADE MECUM FOR THE HOMEWARD BOUND
MONDAY, MARCH 13, 1905.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt are Sicily and Southern Spain. Venice and the district (although they have many attractions) are not uniformly warm until much later. Florence is very beautiful and full of interest, but sometimes there are cold winds in the early spring.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe. They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

row.cell: Port Said or Alexandria to Brindisi
Port Said or Alexandria to Marseilles

div.p: The steamers, of the North German Lloyd, P & O., Orient and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 1/2 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg. The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay. These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: Southern Italy
div.p: The express goes north via Ancona, on the East coast, so that if you elect to go to Naples and Rome you may possibly have to wait at Brindisi some time for your train. At Brindisi there is nothing to see except the place which is supposed to have been the termination of the Appian way from Rome.
From Brindisi to Naples is a journey of 11 hours, but it can be broken at Taranto, two hours run from Brindisi.

Tarentum, founded in the 8th century B.C. by Spartans, was the first city of Great Greece. It has had a varied and exciting history, and remains of fine buildings - theatre, temple, circus and aqueduct - tell of its importance. Its situation is the most picturesque. The bay is the only secure port on the gulf, the entrance being so narrow that is it spanned by a bridge of a seven arches.

Salerno lies on the coast and is one of the most beautiful places in Southern Italy. On a height 905 feet above the sea stand the ruins of its Norman castle, giving a most imposing appearance to the place. The cathedral contains some very fine marble, and an 11th century Byzantine bronze door. Salerno was at one time a seat of learning, its medical school being famous ; the university was closed in 1817. You must visit Pastum's wonderful Greek temples, which are second only to those at Athens. The travertine walls, the gates, the Temples of Neptune and Ceres, and the Basilica are of surpassing interest and the place is a happy hunting ground for the sketcher.

Naples is reached in an hour and a half. Thence you must proceed to Rome, whence you may go by Florence and Bologna to Milan and the Italian Lakes; then by the St. Gothard line to Lucerne, Basle and Calais. Or ou may go by the coast, by Civita Vecchia and Pisu to Genoa and home by Turing and the Mont Cenis route.

div.head: ROUTE I. SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA.

From Messina the railway runs along the north coast of Sicily to Palermo and down the east coast to Syracuse via Taormina and Catania. TAORMINA is one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. The road goes winding up the hill in zig-zag fashion, and charming views - more beautiful the higher one gets - are unfolded to view. In and around the town is much to interest and visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restores under the Roamns. Catania is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, beyond that there is little of interest to the visitor. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless source of pleasure. The finest are at Syracuse and Girgenti on the south-west coast, and both places are well worth visiting. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was besieged by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain - his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. There is a fine theatre, alaso an amphitheatre and a temple to Diana, and the ruins of the great temple dedicated to the Olympian Jove. Girgenti stands on a hill 900 feet high and commands a magnificent view. The ancient ruins of Agrigentum are most interesting - of the timeple to juno there are still many columns stnading. There are also the remains of temples to Castor and Pollux, Theron, and the enormous pillars of the temple to Jupiter Olympus. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Guilia and and Royal Park are also worth a visit. Excursions from Palermo should be made to Monreale to see the beautiful Cloisters, and to Solunto, Cefalu, not forgetting also the Temples of Segesta and Selinunte. With its lovely scenery and delightful climate, its antiquities and beautiful vegetation, Sicily is certainly the most sttractive island in the Mediterranean.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay — Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [or you can drive] will take you on to Capri. This rocky little island is full of beautiful sea caves and grottoes, the exploring of which on a fine day, in a small boat, is a most fascinating occupation. The colour of the water is a perpetual joy, and the caves seem to be a veritable trap for sunshine. Of flowers and ferns there are plenty. Ischia and Procida can be visited in another little three or four days' trip from Naples. The steamers start from Immacolatella. The views of the coast, of Posilipo, Pozzuoli and Capo Miseno, are very fine. The little volcanic island of Procida is chiefly inhabited by sailors. The island of Ischia comes next, a charming resort, with mineral waters. The little harbour of Ischia, protected by its castle on a promontorv, is a volcanic crater. Casamieciola is the place at which you will stay, and from which you will make the ascent of Mount Epomeus for a glorious view.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but a few hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here. But a list of the principal attractions may not be out of place : - St. Peter's, the Vatican, Capitol and National Museums, Gallery of Modern Art, Villa Borghese, Doria, Colonna, and Lateran Palaces, Castle of St. Angelo, and the Pagan Antiquities, consisting of the Colosseum, Roman Forum, etc.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spen admiring the City of Flowers and its sur rounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with the Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes about an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

The run down to Pisa from Florence can be made two ways; either by Pistoja and Lucca or by Empoli. Lucea is one of the old fortified towns of Italy, with an imposing wall built round it, and massive gates leading into the town. Here is also the fine old Cathedral of St. Martino. In Pisa there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset. From Pisa there are good trains to Leghorn, where you can take boat to Genoa and thence to the Riviera or Milan and The Lakes.

div.head: ROUTE II. NORTHERN ITALY. Italian Lakes Italian & French Riviera
div.p: GENOA (La Superba). -The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest deathaverages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature —warm in winter and | deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and his-torical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.

Genoa is the principal port on the Mediter-­ranean, and the first commercial and shipping point of the Littoral, besides being the junction for the arrival and departure for all the principal cities of Europe, the Orient, and the United States, the Hamburg American, and North-German-Lloyd steamers from New York, and the Continent of Europe en route to China and Japan, stop at Genoa. The trains-de-luxe, and regular express trains from Paris and other large Continental cities make connections at Genoa en route to the Italian and French Rivieras, so that travellers to Rome, Naples, Alassio, San Remo, Nice. Mentone, Monte Carlo, etc., can arrange to spend a few davs in Genoa at one of its fine modern hotels. Genoa is built on steep hills rising abruptly from the Mediterranean, and the gorgeous panoramic views afforded from almost any terrace, street or building, must be seen to be appreciated Electric trams traverse every part, and tend to add the combination of the modern with all that is most ancient and in-teresting to the American tourist, who is doubly interested in seeing the birthplace of Christopher Columbus, the discoverer of America.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before: making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

VENICE is a 5 hour journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most, delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is un-like that of any other seaport. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.

From Venice you can go to Bologna via Padua; and then to Ravenna, one of the most ancient towns in Italy. Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour-and-a-half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San-Donino, and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

TYROL, INNSBRUCK, one of the finest and prettiest towns in the German Austrian Mountains, is 600 metres above sea level, and has many interesting features, both ancient and modern. It is admirably suited for spring and summer residence, and is a good centre for excursions in the summer months. There are three good railway services, via. Germany, Switzerland and Italy. Electric tramcars run constantly to many places of local interest. The Hotels are good, as also several Pensions, all being equipped with modern requirements. Full particulars and information can be obtained from any of Cook's offices.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.

COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza; also by tramway in two-and-a-half hours. The cathedral, entirely of marble, is one of the finest in N. Italy—1426-1526 a.d.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Caddenubbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellagio opposite. These four latter towns are in about the centre of the lake, and very close together, and the walk from. Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

Lake Maggiore is 37 miles long and varies in width from one-and-a-half miles to three miles, and though the banks are not generally so mountainous as those of the Lake of Como, the scenery is pretty and there are many in-teresting spots-at which to stay.

Pallanza, opposite the Borromean Isles, is well situated for a fine view over the Lake and the Alps. It is an interesting town and a good centre for making a tour round the Lake. Steamers are very frequent to all other towns up or down the Lake. Taking the steamer from Pallanza for Stresa, you call at Baveno, a pretty little spot where Queen Victoria stayed in 1879. Then you come to the most charming feature of this part of the Lake, the Borromean Islands. Isola Superiore is only a fishing hamlet, but Isola Bella is a picture. The castle was built in the 17th century and is worth visiting as well as the grounds. Stresa, the next stopping place by the steamer, is cooler and has a better air than places on the opposite side of the Lake, so that for the summer months it is a more preferable spot at which to stay.

div.head: Route III. Switzerland
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and granduers." The country has an area of only 15,720 square miles, and borders on France, Germany, Austria and Italy. It also has the proud distinction of being the source of three of Europe's biggest waterways - the rivers Rhine, Danube and Rhone. Mountains and lakes occupy almost the whole of Switzerland, there being practically no flat land or plains. The mountains or Alps are divided into three groups, the Pennine Alps, Helvetic Alps, and the Rhoetic Alps. The principal lakes are Constance, Geneva, Zurich, Lucerne and Neuchatel, then the lakes of Bienne, Thun, Brienz and Zug. The glaciers of Switzerland occupy about one-eighteenth of the space, and are about 400 in number, the principal of which is the Aletsch Glacier. There are also waterfalls of importance, such as the Rhine at Schaffhausen, the Aar at Handeck, Staubbach and Pletschbach at Lauterbrunnen, etc., etc.

Certain points are renowned for the view and may be selected as follows: - Col de la Faucille, near M. Reculets and M. Dole, above St. Cergue near Geneva, Chaumont above Neuchatel, Macolin above Bienne, the Hauen-steing above Olten, Albis between Zurich and Zug, Rigi between Zug and Lucerne, etc.

It depends very much on the point at which Switzerland is first entered which is to be the first stopping place; also whether the tour is on bicycle or foot, as naturally the cyclist wishes to be ever going from place to place and never turning back along the same road. But as centres for seeing the beauties and charms of each certain district the following may be helpful to visitors:- LAUSANNE as centre for Montreux, Vevey, Neuchatel, St. Maurice, Martigny, Aigle, Bex. etc. INTERLAKEN for the Bernese Oberland, Grindelwald, Murren, Lake Brienz, Thun, etc. CHUR for the Engadine, St. Mortiz, Davos Platz, Pontresina, Klosters, Ragatz, etc. ZURICH, Dolder, Schaffhausen.

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M, de Caprino and M. Generoso.

The Piazza Giardino, with its promenade and fountains, is close to the landing stage. A broad quay, the favorite promenade, extends the whole length of the town along the shores of the lake. In the Santa Maria degli Angiolo is a fresco of the Passion, the finest work of Bernardino Luini (1529). There are many interesting excursions to be made into the surrounding neighbourhood. MONTE GENEROSO, about 5,600 feet, is reached by taking steamer or train from Lugano to Capolago, then the mountain railway, which runs to the summit. The view is magnificent, being one of the finest in the Lombard Alps. Monte Salvatore is ascended by railway from Lugano Paradiso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bel-inzona in forty minutes. This pretty town situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna de Sasso, situated above the town is worth a visit, as it contains interst-ing paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and "The Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.

LUCERNE. - A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne is surrounded by walls with nine watch towers facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps. Seven bridges cross the Reuss, but the two old ones, the Kapell Brucke and Muhlen Brucke are of interest. Both have roofs, the former painted with scenes from the letter with a Dance of Death. The old water tower near the Kapell Brucke used to be a lighthouse or "Lucerna," giving its name to the town. In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous. Places of interest in the town are the Hof Kirche, dating from the 16th Century, the Lion of Lucerne Monument, near which is also an interesting garden, containing signs of glacier-worn rocks of a remote ice period. In the Bathaus is a Museum (War and Peace Museum) should also be visited.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgent stock and Sonnenberg, needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

The Rigi is a famous ridge between the Lakes Lucerne and Zug. The view is unsur-passed for extent and magnificence, including the view of 13 lakes, the Oberland, and many of the distant Alps. The sunset view is much finer than sunrise, and is best seen from the Roth-stock. Sunrise from Kulum.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of the lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axenstrasse.
SEELISBERG is on the opposite shore to Brunnen, and with the Sanitorium of Sonnen-berg forms one of the famous health resorts of the Lake of Lucerne

THE BURGENSTOCK may be reached in two ways; either by steamer from Lucerne to Kehrsiten, then the cable railway to the crest of Burgenstock; or the other way is to go to Stannstad by boat, and then drive up the fine new road. From Stannstad it is about 1 hour 40 minutes by electric railway to ENGLEBERG. The ascent of Titlis is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand, extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

ZURICH, capital of Canton Zurich, is beautifully situated in a mountain valley 1,300 ft above the sea. As a commercial tewn t is perhaps the most important in Switzer-land, having extensive manufactures in silk, cotton, and machinery. The old town is still picturesque, but is gradually being replaced by modern private dwellings and public buildings, amongst which is the Federal Polytechnic School and University. An interesting excur-sion is that to the Zurichberg 2,000 ft. above the sea, from which a fine sunset view can be obtained. Another favourite place is the Uttli-berg, about 6 miles south-west of Zurich.

div.head: Route III. - Contd.
div.p: THE ENGADINE - Coire. (Chur) is the best starting point for the Engatine, and from here carriages may may be had for all parts.
Thusis can be reached by rail in about an hour and a half, and here are the ruins of the oldest castle in Switzerland.
AROSA, six hours by diligence from Coire about 6,000 ft. aboce tho sea, magnificent scenery, and a favourite Alpine summer resort.
DAVOS. - Health resort with dry bracing air and much sinshine. In winter skating, tobogganing and snow shoeing are the amusements, in summer golf, and lovely local excursions are made.
KLOSTERS, situated in a broad valley amongst pastures and woods and surrounded by lofty mountains, is a much frequented sum-mer resort with several interesting mountain excursions.

ST. MORTIZ, 6,000 ft. above the sea, and the highest village in the Engadine consists of two parts St. Moritz Dorf and St. Moritz Bad. The latter is the summer resort during the months of May to September when golf, tennis, boating on the lake and Glacier excur-sions are the pastimes. St. Moritz Dorf during the winter season is frequented by lovers of winter sports such as skating, curling, tobogganing and ice sailing on the lake.
PONTRESINA. - Quite a popular summer resort, and much frequented by English visitors for its delightful excursions to several glaciers. St. Moritz Dorf is only an hour's walk through the forest.

THE BERNESE OBERLAND. - INTER-LAKEN is situated, as its name says, "between the lakes" the Lakes of Brienz and Thun; a fovourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Heheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees a chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Gressbach on Lake Brienz, Trummelbach and Staubbach in the Valley of Lauterbrunnen. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and views from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

Lauterbrunnen is only one hour by rail from Interlaken and here are the famous waterfalls of Staubbach (with a direct drop of 1,000 ft.) and Trummelback. From Lauterbrunnen to Murren is about an hour by electric railway.
MURREN is celebrated for the finest view of Alpine scenery to be had from any residential spot. The ascent of the Schilthorn can be made from here in about 4 hours.
Scheidegg is the starting place of the Jungfrau Railway, which ascends at present to a height of over 9,000 ft.

GRINDELWALD from Interlaken, about 1 hour 20 minutes, is a favourite centre for moun-tain excursions, and much frequented during sum-mer. It is sheltered by the Wetterhorn (12,000 ft.), Mettenberg (10,000 ft.) and Eiger (13,000 ft.), and between these three giants are two famous glaciers, the Ober and Unter Grindelwald, the Ober being the most popular.
ST. BEATENBERG, a charming place and favourite health resort, with fine lake and mountain scenery, 50 minutes from Interlaken by boat and funicular.
Brienz, at the north end of Lake Brienz, noted for wood carving, is worth a visit.

Other places which can be visited from Interlaken are Kandersteg (commanidng a magnificent panorama), Adelboden, Reichen-bach and Frutigen. Zermatt and the Rhone Valley can be reached from Kandersteg by way of the Gemmi Pass.

LAUSANNE itself is a mile-and-a-half from the shore of the lake up in the centre of the Jorat Hills. The port for landing from the steamer is Ouchy, roughly 30 miles from Geneva. The old and new parts of Lausanne are joined by a very fine bridge 135 yards long, called the Grand Pont, or sometimes Pont Pichard after the builder. The cathedral dates from the 13th century, and is a fine gothic edifice, the approach to the terrace of the cathedral is by 160 steps, or by a winding street, but the views are very fine from the terrace. Other interesting places are the cantonal museum, Musee Aarlaud, blind asylum, etc. Leaving Ouchy by steamer you come to Pully, Cully, then Vevey, famous as the scene of Rousseau's romance Nouvelle Heloise. Here also are important factories for tobacco, chocolate and infants food.

MONTREUX is composed of scattered villages partly on the hillside, partly on the late, and is divided into three parts, Le Chatelard, Les Planches, and Veytaux. Many excursions can be made from Montreux; to Vevey by electric tram, cable tram to Glion, having another fine view of the lake and surrounding mountains can be obtained, then to Naye, 6,500 feet, from where can be seen the Bernese Alps (Wetterhorn, Eiger, Jungfrau, etc.) Les Avants can be reached from Montreux by road, via Glion, and the fields of narcissus are a lovely sight in early summer.
Continuing on by rail, you pass Territet, Villeneuve, Aigle, Bex, St. Maurice, and the come to Martigny.

AIGLE, 20 minutes from Montreux is the starting point to the health resorts of Leysin, Diablerets, Chateau d'Oex (for its bracing mountain air cures); Villars (for milk cures, and lovely scenery); Chesieres and Bex (noted for its strong saline waters and grape cures). Near Bex is Les Plans for climatic cure, 3,600 ft., and a centre for mountain excursions.

Martigny is the starting place for the Tete Noir and Col-de-Balme routes to Chamonix, one of the most popular Alpine resorts, on account of being within easy reach of the famous Mer-de-Glace Clacier des Bossons. The ascent of Mont Blanc is made from here, and needs usually two days.

Champery, situated at the foot of the Dent-du-Midi, is reached by diligence from Monthey. From Martigny the railway goes to Brigue (the terminus of the Simplon and Furka routes) via Sion (starting point for Evolena, Arolla, Mayens, etc., and Viege (Visp) the junction of the line to ZERMATT. This last plce is a very important mountaineering centre, whence the ascent of Monte Rosa, the Matter-horn, Dome, Dent Blanche and the Breithorn can be made. The view of the snow-covered Alps and glaciers obtained from the railway to Gornergrat is really magnificent.

Eggshorn is a high mountain resort on the Brigue-Rhone Glacier road, whence the ascent of the Jungfrau is made quite easily. There are also numerous Glacier excursions, notably that to the Aletsch Glacier the largest in Switzerland.

div.head: Route IV. Greece and the Ionian Isles. Constantinople
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alex-andria; the climate in April is charming. Steamers run frequently both to Putras, and the Piraeus - which is the port for Athens. The advantage of disembarking at the latter place is that it is but five miles from Athens, which may be reached in twenty minutes by train; while the railway journey from Patras takes about 7 1/2 hours. The best steamers are those of the Khedival Mail Co. Greece is also very easily reached from either Smyrna or Constan-tinople; and there are frequent sailings by excellent steamers.

The first and most important sit to visit in ATHENS is, of course, the Acropolis - a rocky platform upon which were built some of the most famous buildings of classic times. Ascend-ing the great staircase, 70 ft. wide, and passing throuhg the Gateway built of marble from Pentelicus the Parthenon is reached - dedicated to Pa'las Athene by Pericles cir. 444 B.C., and adorned with priceless sculptures, many of which are now in the British Museum. There is the Erechtheion with its celebrated Caryatides; the Theseion and the beautiful little Temple of the Wingless Vistory. Close to the Acropolis lies Mars Hill, celebrated as the site where St. Paul preached to the Athenians, and where the Athenians held their public cCourt. On the Pnyx immediatley behind they assembled their meetings. On the south and south-east sides of the Acropolis are the beautiful columns of the Temple of Jupiter Olympus and the triumphal arch of Hadrian, the Temple of Aesculapius and the two ancient theatres - the Odeum, and the Theatre of Dionysus which is well preserved. These are but a few of the interesting buildings of ancient Athens.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara, for which a special train is run from Athens.

A charming trip can be made to Corinth by train (3 hours) through lovely scenery, and on to Mycenae, where can be seen the celebrated Tomb of Atreus and the Gate of Lions at the entrnce to Agamemmnons's Palace. From here it is quite possible to drive via Argos to Nauplia in the day. This is an interesting town, and the surrounding scenery is lovely. A pleasant afternoon's drive can be made to Tiryns with its Cyclopoean masonry, and to Argos with fine amphitheatre cut in the natural rock, and Acropolis 1,000 ft. above sea level. Epidaurus with its Temple of Aesculapius and very perfect amphitheatre is well worth the day's driving excursion. From Nauplia you can get to Olympia by rail via Pyrgos - the scenery is most picturesque. It is here that the celebrated Olympic games were help from B.C. 776 to A.D. 394 - the stadium is very perfect. The ruins of the Temple of Jupiter are quite splendid. The famous statue of Hermes is here. Patras is reached from Pyrgos by rail in ofur hours, from which port steamers to all parts of Europe run frequently. A charming trip can be made among the Ionian islands, Zanta, Cephalonia, etc. It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
You will get at Alexandria vessels belonging to different lines that will take you by various routes to Constantinople. The Khedivial stea-mers go by Piraeus for visiting Athens.
It is a great advantage to see Constantinople for the first time from the sea, the view of the city fom the Golden Horn being magnificent
The chief things to see in Constantinople are the Mosque of San Sophia, the Golden Horn and the Valley of Sweet Waters.

Smyrna is a thriving commercial port, at which many steamers call. Many charming excursions can be made from it; to the Cyclo-poean Cities of Nymphaeum and Sipylus and the rock-cut City of Niobe near Magnesia; the Baths of Diana and Agamemnon; and the Meles Valley, where may be seen the Chair and Cave of Homer and a fire double-arched acqueduct.

there is a railway to Ephesus where there is a good Hotel and Restaurant kept by an Englishman. The ruins of the Great Temple of Diana are about three-quarters of a mile distant. Of the "Seven churches of Asia." five are ac-cessible by tain from Smyrna. Laodicea can be reached from Alascheir which is 50 miles distant by rail and is the site of Philadelphus.
This is a beautiful old City at the foot of Mt. Tmolus; it was built in B.C. 160 by Attalus Philadelphus, last King of Pergamos.

div.head: Palestine and Syria
div.p: The nearest port from Egypt in Jaffa, the ancient Joppa. You can take steamer from Alexandria or Port Said to Jaffa or any of the Syrian ports. Probably the largest steamers on route are those of the Messageries Maritimes. There are Austrian Lloyd, and Khedivial steamers, and also occasional Moss, and Price line steamers. You must on no account forget to obtain a special passport for Palestine before leaving Egypt, or you will find much difficulty at the ports.

The landing at Jaffa is most exciting. As there is no harbour, the steamer drops anchor as near as she safely can to the shore, and large row boats come out to take off the passengers. A great reef through which there is only one small opening protects the coast, and the interesting moment is the passing through this opening in the row boat. There is not much to detain you at Jaffa, though there are two excellent hotels outside the town. There is a railway to Jerusalem, also an excellent carriage road, the drive occupying about eight hours.

The trip from Jerusalem to Jericho can be made by carriage or by riding. The drive is very fine, the views of the steep ravine of the Wady Kelt (the Book Cherith) with the monastery clinging to its side, and of the Dead Sea and Jordan Valley being very fine.

Fom Jerusalem to Damascus by land, is a camping tour of about a fortnight. The route is by Nablous - the ancient Samaritan Shechem - Jenin, Haifa, (Mount Carmel), Nazareth, Tiberias, Tell Hum (Capernaum), Safed and Banias (Caesarea Philippi). There are other camping expeditions possible from Jerusalem, as, from Jerusalem via Nazareth and Haifa, Tyre and Sidon to Beyrout, whence there is a rail to Damascus.
